messages.text:
I don't know if people here use `GAP.jl`, but I have a question on it. I've let `D = GAP.Globals` for convenience but am running into this
```julia> D.IsSubgroup(<http://D.GL|D.GL>(4,3), <http://D.GL|D.GL>(2,3))
false```
Was wondering if anyone know what is going on. (x/posted to <#C66NPKCQZ|maths>)

messages.text: hi, author of GAP.jl here. A 2x2 matrix group can't be a subgroup of a 4x4 matrix group.

elements.text: hi, author of GAP.jl here. A 2x2 matrix group can't be a subgroup of a 4x4 matrix group.

messages.text: Yeah Thanks I've realised the problem. I have to manually filter the elements of the 4 by 4 matrix groups to get the subgroup I wanted.

elements.text: Yeah Thanks I've realised the problem. I have to manually filter the elements of the 4 by 4 matrix groups to get the subgroup I wanted.

messages.text: Does anyone who uses Singular.jl know how to find the generators for a radical of an ideal? I see an old PR which said some other merged PR superceded it but fail to find the needed functionality.

messages.text: Hi all!  Does any one have Peter Luschny’s contact details, *or* know the maths behind this `isPerfectPower`<https://github.com/OpenLibMathSeq/IntegerSequences.jl/blob/master/src/IntegerSequences.jl#L6458| function>?  I spent a long time trying to port some DJB algorithms into Julia (unsuccessfully; [<https://cr.yp.to/papers/powers.pdf|1>], [<https://cr.yp.to/lineartime/powers2-20060914-ams.pdf|2>]), and Peter’s implementation using Nemo’s `isprime`, `factor`, and `fmpz` functions seems remarkably simple—and *efficient*!

from that link you used above:
```Return a list of perfect powers of length len. (Numbers of the form ``p^k`` where ``p`` is a prime and ``k ≥ 2``.```

messages.text: for me, a perfect power is a number of the form `a^k` with `a` an integer, and `k > 1` also an integer. For loc cit, a is restricted to be a prime

elements.text: for me, a perfect power is a number of the form
also an integer. For loc cit, a is restricted to be a prime

messages.text: seems <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perfect_power|Wikipedia agrees with me> -- good, because that's what I've been teaching my students all these years :joy:

attachments.title: Perfect power
attachments.text: In mathematics, a perfect power is a positive integer that can be resolved into equal factors, and whose root can be exactly extracted, i.e., a positive integer that can be expressed as an integer power of another positive integer. More formally, n is a perfect power if there exist natural numbers m > 1, and k > 1 such that mk = n. In this case, n may be called a perfect kth power. If k = 2 or k = 3, then n is called a perfect square or perfect cube, respectively. Sometimes 0 and 1 are also considered perfect powers (0k = 0 for any k > 0, 1k = 1 for any k).

elements.text: -- good, because that's what I've been teaching my students all these years

messages.text:
anyway, if you are interested in this kind of prime powers, check out Hecke, which defines `ispower`:
```  ispower(a::fmpz) -> Int, fmpz
  ispower(a::Integer) -> Int, Integer

  Returns e, r such that a = r^e with e maximal. Note: 1 = 1^0.```

elements.text: anyway, if you are interested in this kind of prime powers, check out Hecke, which defines
